conclusion: To determine the speed of the elevator at t = 60 seconds, we need to analyze the acceleration-time graph provided.
The speed of the elevator can be found by calculating the area under the acceleration-time graph, as this area represents the change in velocity.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the acceleration increases linearly from 0 to 2 m/s².
From t = 1 to t = 4 seconds, the acceleration is constant at 2 m/s².
From t = 4 to t = 5 seconds, the acceleration decreases linearly from 2 m/s² to 0.
From t = 5 to t = 55 seconds, the acceleration is 0.
From t = 55 to t = 56 seconds, the acceleration decreases linearly from 0 to -2 m/s².
From t = 56 to t = 59 seconds, the acceleration is constant at -2 m/s².
From t = 59 to t = 60 seconds, the acceleration increases linearly from -2 m/s² to 0.

premise: Segment 1 (0 to 1 second): This is a triangle with base 1 second and height 2 m/s².
Segment 2 (1 to 4 seconds): This is a rectangle with width 3 seconds and height 2 m/s².
Segment 3 (4 to 5 seconds): This is a triangle with base 1 second and height 2 m/s².
Segment 4 (5 to 55 seconds): The acceleration is 0.
Segment 5 (55 to 56 seconds): This is a triangle with base 1 second and height -2 m/s².
Segment 6 (56 to 59 seconds): This is a rectangle with width 3 seconds and height -2 m/s².
Segment 7 (59 to 60 seconds): This is a triangle with base 1 second and height -2 m/s².
